text: @Axman6 I lodged a bug at http://hackage.haskell.org/trac/gtk2hs/ticket/1175 - feel like adding any useful context?

@Axman6 Hell yes. See you there... reckon it's the sort of conference where people adjourn to the bar after? Lots of good pubs in newtown.
nice chunky #haskell talks at SAPLING http://bit.ly/8MOZG
@bos31337 i got half an hour in the airport... well, an extra two hours waiting on the ground in the plane, but i don't think that counts.
+1. kill the hashtable. @bos31337 Need your benchmarking lib so I can put some nails in the coffin. http://bit.ly/nGVCH (via @donsbot)
mainlining coffee in San Francisco in order to get on Sydney time. I laugh in the face of circadian cycles.
She still wouldn't be as dirty as you, mate. RT @bacek I wish to have girlfriend as dirty as my car
@jamesbritt ha. which song? "include me out" still sends me into a weird trance.
@quackingduck If I did I'd be sitting on my own island:) but it's a useful thought experiment, i think. How valuable can a yes/no answer be?
@bacek left the happy pills at home http://bit.ly/mTBit
@quackingduck about your assertion that all useful code is user interfaces - an NP solver returns one bit, and changes everything...
@nkpart it's really just a special case of the question of when to evaluate constructs. I wish I had more control even in #haskell.
hungry, tired, in Portland #fb

What do Turing, Shannon, and Dijkstra have in common? Blistering rejection notices, obviously... http://bit.ly/3puYN3 (via @copumpkin)
finally watching the Haskell videos from HIW in Edinburgh, worried that I'm not hairy enough to be a #haskell hacker.
just tacked on an extra 3km to what should have been a 5km walk. Navigation fail. (Also, blister fail.) http://bit.ly/Bfp0Y #fb
@robgreayer 14000 lines of haskell ought to be enough to instantiate God.
@gimboland this is half the reason to go point-free. If it's not worth naming something better than "x", it's not worth naming at all.
wonder how hard it would be to rejig a twitter client so you saw retweets as annotations on the original, rather than endless repeats...
@vornstar oh, you did go... it's a good group, hey. How was shane's talk? Sorry to miss it...
@AndrePang people actually use Automator?
@TacticalGrace bloody-mindedness works every time, even if the results are not pretty.
@gimboland Haskell is just Forth with graceful degradation for named arguments :)
@gimboland I don't think it matters, does it? I can't check your original code, but it should be a one-liner - you removed the do, right?
You should backup your tweets here: http://backupmytweets.com It's free! (please retweet)
@gimboland fglToFsm = polishFSM . fromList . graphActions :) point-free FTW.
.@donsbot cheers mate. requires a couple of patches, but they're minor. http://bit.ly/KIse9
should probably stop looking at Haskell and get my Ocaml on. Interview looms...
First build of Hubris Haskell-Ruby bridge working on Mac w/ GHC HEAD! #haskell #ruby #hubris #ghc
@jlloydph I'm going :)
@TacticalGrace do you rate VirtualBox over VMware?
@donsbot good to see you're still repping the antipodeans
@bacek yeah, that's what i'm using and what's breaking. Works great on Linux, falls in a heap on Mac.
@AndrePang you're a disturbing man. Although I _was_ using sshfs for a while, this really is the obvious next step.
is so damn close to getting Hubris working on Mac. Why do you hate me so, -rpath?

@iws hey, I was getting that problem too. http://bit.ly/r3vjV Did you fix it?
ruby scoping considered humourous.
when you break GHC, you get to keep both pieces
looking forward to a decent benchmark library: RT @bos31337 It's been a productive few weeks of Haskell hacking: http://bit.ly/ykOeK

wondering if using the GHC API would have made more sense...
interview done, time for jelly at @agencyrainford...
@jlloydph Nowhere's a good spot. Good thinking on the drinks, most people on the road to Nowhere forget...
current release of Hubris works with GHC 6.11 on Linux, handles arrays, jackknifes juggernauts: http://bit.ly/K9I20 #haskell #hubris #ruby
@DRMacIver you're such a conflict junkie
@shapr wget -r? HTML is not just for HTTP!
just implemented dylib caching for #hubris. Who needs arrays or installability when you can have Raw Blazing Speed, right? *back to work*
@joshprice what do you think of the syntax for jruby wrapping? worth nicking for Hubris? http://bit.ly/OL3Cr
@lightningdb cheers dave. Yeah, it sort of got practical in the last few years, not quite sure how that happened :)
RORO talk slides are up at http://www.slideshare.net/mwotton/hubris #hubris #haskell #ruby #roro

RORO talk went surprisingly smoothly. Almost convinced I'm not completely full of crap. #haskell #ruby #roro #hubris #hashtagoverload
time to make a fool of myself in public #roro #fb
writing slides right up to the talk, same as always.

@charleshdale terrible reason not to go. just terrible.


... but i hope you feel better soon :/
do a little dance, make a dynamic library, link in GHC tonight... :)
in today's lesson, mark learns that having 40 dylibs in the one directory is not great for performance
@TacticalGrace ah, i misspoke - algorithmic complexity is the same, the cost of the (++) is swallowed up in the partition step.
@donsbot i think those are ok - you're illustrating different ways to run a known algorithm, not showing off brevity to newbies.
@TacticalGrace sure, but the quicksort in particular borders on dishonest. QS with > O(n log n) average runtime is not QS.
@donsbot your examples in RWH was meaty as hell. It's the fib/quicksort/eratosthenes one-liners that bug me.
to expand - I don't agree with @dozba, but there's a lamentable tendency to choose cute, short, unrealistic examples for #haskell tutes.
As bad as faux-quicksort #haskell RT @dozba if you read the tutorials, the only thing haskell is good at is generating fibonacci numbers.
@madradish only did one phone interview, and i think there are about 7 more. celebration is a little premature, but thanks :)
rates his perl skills as 9/10 purely to piss off @bacek
stupidly nervous about google interview, but went ok. the first of many - probably just shows i don't drool on my keyboard...
replacing Control.Applicative.<$> calls with unsafePerformIO and half expecting a raptor attack.
anyone going to be in New York on the 18th? Got a job interview and am hoping to see the city before i come back.
spent all day on paid work. no fun.
hopelessly jealous of #haskell hackers in edinburgh
using git as a database for binary objects, because, y'know, i had this hammer...
contemplating the possibility of a trip to NY
@DRMacIver I thought the point of xmonad was that it was meant to get out of your way...
@hotdogsladies i'm an old-school unix nerd. i love the terminal, i think in hex, and i'm still not going to upgrade my OS until it's safe.
@leastlikely starting to think calling my Ruby-Haskell bridge "Hubris" was an unfortunate collision.
@G3rtm yes. but GHC changes hugely every release anyway, you can't really get away from it.
Apple adds blocks to C, calls it C, news at 11. http://bit.ly/74TT2
tempted by an SSD for the mac. any #haskell hackers want to comment on whether it helped with the interminable GHC compile cycles?
playing with amazon ec2 - googled for "ec2 small ami", got "Conquer Your Ejaculation & Erection Problems Today." #advertisingfail
80c an hour, i mean.
playing around with one of the 20 core EC2 instances. 80c a minute, and ferociously fast... this could be a good jhc/ghc buildserver.
wishing there was a version of the cvs-ghc which didn't get 5mb of text a month... ~200k of text a day is a lot to wade through.
